facts.text: The appellant is a firm acting as managing agents of the Janardana Mills Ltd., Coimbatore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a firm acting as managing agents of the Janardana Mills Ltd., Coimbatore. It purchased four contiguou

facts.text: Appellant purchased four contiguous plots of land admeasuring 5 acres 26 cents under four sale deeds on October 25, 1941, November 15, 1941, June 29, 1942, and November 19, 1942 for total Rs. 8,712-15-6.

anchor.surface_text: s plots of land admeasuring 5 acres 26 cents under four sale deeds executed on October 25, 1941, November 15, 1941, June 29, 1942, and November 19, 1942, respectively for a total consideration of Rs. 8,712-15-6.

facts.text: Properties sold by appellant in two lots to Janardana Mills Ltd. on September 1, 1947 and November 10, 1947 for total Rs. 52,600.

anchor.surface_text: After about five years these properties were sold by the appellant in two lots to the Janardana Mills Ltd. The first lot was sold on September 1, 1947, and the second on November 10, 1947, the total consideration for the two sales being Rs. 52,600.

facts.text: Sales realised Rs.43,887-0-6 in excess of purchase price.

anchor.surface_text: These two sales realised for the appellant a sum of Rs.43,887-0-6 in excess of the purchase price.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer treated Rs. 43,887 as income of appellant for assessment year 1948-49 under head 'business'.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer treated the said amount of Rs. 43,887 as the income of the appellant for the assessment year 1948- 49, and assessed it to income-tax under the head business .

facts.text: ITO held no evidence of purchase for agricultural purposes or investment; lands adjacent to mills, purchased to sell to mills at profit; solitary transaction but adventure in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: The officer held that there was no evidence to show that the appellant had purchased the said lands for agricultural purposes or that it had acquired them as an investment. He also found that, since the lands were adjacent to the Janar- dana Mills, the appellant must have purchased them solely with a view to sell them to the said mills with a profit.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who set aside ITO order holding amount not assessable.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of assessment the appellant preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The appellate authority upheld the appellants contention that the amount in question was not assessable as it cannot be hold to be income or profit resulting from a profit-making scheme, and set aside the order under appeal.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld ITO view, held amount gain from adventure in nature of business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the correctness of this order by taking an appeal against it to the Incometax Appellate Tribunal. The tribunal agreed with the view taken by the Income-tax Officer and held that the amount in question was not a capital accretion but a gain made in an adventure in the nature of business in carrying out a scheme of profit-making.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected appellant's explanations for purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal rejected the explanations given by the appellant as to why it had purchased the properties and held that the purchase had been made by the appellant solely with a view to sell the said properties at profit to the Janardana Mills.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Madras High Court: whether material for assessing Rs. 43,887 as income from adventure in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant the tribunal then referred to the High Court of Madras the question suggested by it in these words whether there was material for the assessment of the sum of Rs. 43,887 being the difference between the purchase and sale price of the four plots of land as income from an adventure in the nature of trade .

facts.text: Madras High Court (Rajagopalan and Rajagopala Ayyangar JJ) answered against appellant on April 18, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Rajagopalan and Rajagopala Ayyangar, JJ., and the question referred has been answered against the appellant. The High Court has held that the transaction in question was an adventure in the nature of trade and so the respondent was justified in taxing the amount in question under the head business for the relevant year.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 709 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Civil APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 709 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 18, 1955, of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 25 of 1952.

facts.text: First purchase for Rs. 521, 28 1/4 cents.

anchor.surface_text: The first purchase was for Rs. 521 and it covered a piece of land admeasuring 281 cents

facts.text: Second purchase 2 acres 79 1/2 cents for Rs. 1,250.

anchor.surface_text: the second purchase related to 2 acres 791 cents and the price paid was Rs. 1,250

facts.text: Third purchase 28 1/4 cents for Rs. 1,942; fourth 1 acre 90 cents for Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: while the third and the fourth purchases were for Rs. 1,942 and Rs. 5,000 and they covered 28 1/4 cents and 1 acre and 90 cents respectively.

facts.text: First item sold November 10, 1947 for Rs. 2,825; remaining three September 1, 1947 for Rs. 49,775 to Janardana Mills.

anchor.surface_text: The property purchased under the first sale deed was sold on November 10, 1947, for Rs. 2,825 whereas the three remaining properties were sold on September 1, 1947, for Rs. 49,775, the purchaser in both cases being the Janardana Mills Ltd.

facts.text: First purchase in name of Mr. G. Raja, assistant manager of Janardana Mills, son-in-law of partner G. Venkataswami Naidu; benami for appellant, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: The purchase of the first item of property by the appellant had been made in the name of Mr. G. Raja, assistant manager of the Janardana Mills Ltd., who is the son-in-law Of G. Venkataswami Naidu, one of the partners of the appellant firm. ... It is not disputed that the purchase in the name of V. G. Raja was benami for the appellant.

facts.text: All plots contiguous and adjoin the mills.

anchor.surface_text: All the plots which were thus purchased by the appellant piecemeal are contiguous and they adjoin the mills.

facts.text: On plot purchased June 29, 1942, house of six rooms, annual rent Rs. 100, net Rs. 80 after taxes.

anchor.surface_text: On the plot purchased on June 29, 1942, there stood a house of six rooms which fetched an annual rent of about Rs. 100 and after deduction of taxes, it left a net income of Rs. 80 per year to the appellant.

facts.text: Other plots vacant, no income; no effort to build or cultivate.

anchor.surface_text: The other plots are vacant sites and they brought no income to the appellant. During the time that the appellant was in possession of these plots it made no effort to put up any structures on them or to cultivate them

facts.text: Appellant urged properties bought as investment; rejected by tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and so it was clear that the only object with which the appellant had purchased these plots was to sell them to the mills at a profit. It was, however, urged by the appellant that the properties had been bought as an investment. This plea was rejected by the tribunal.

facts.text: Appellant case: purchased for building tenements for mill labourers; rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal likewise rejected the appellants case that it had purchased the plots for building tenements for the labourers working in the Janardana Mills.

facts.text: Alternatively, mills purchased due to industrial tribunal award in June 1947 recommending tenements.

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively it was urged by the appellant that the Janardana Mills decided to purchase the plots because an award passed by an industrial tribunal in June 1947 had recommended that the mills should provide tenements for its labourers.

facts.text: Tribunal held plots purchased solely to sell at profit to mills; appellant as managing agent could influence.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the appellants case was that it had not purchased the properties with a view to sell them to the mills and the mills in fact would not have purchased them but for the recommendation made by the award which made it necessary for the mills to purchase the adjoining plots for the purpose of building tenements for its employees. The tribunal was not impressed even by this plea and so it ultimately held that the plots had been purchased by the appellant wholly and solely, with the idea of selling them at profit to the mills.

facts.text: Supreme Court held transaction is adventure in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was right in taking the view that, on the facts and circumstances proved in this case, the transaction in question is an adventure in the nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the jurisdiction conferred on the High Court by s. 66(1) is limited to entertaining references involving questions of law. ... only such questions as relate to one or the other of the following matters can be questions of law under s. 66(1): (1) the construction of a statute or a document of title (2) the legal effect of the facts found where the point for determination is a mixed question of law and fact and (3) a finding of fact unsupported by evidence or unreasonable and perverse in nature.

holdings.text: The transaction in question is an adventure in the nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was right in taking the view that, on the facts and circumstances proved in this case, the transaction in question is an adventure in the nature of trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor test to primary facts: appellant not land trader but managing agent of mills; contiguous plots adjoining mills acquired piecemeal; no cultivation/building/pride of possession; sole intention to resell at profit to mills (strong unrebutted presumption); position enabled influence.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade and taxing under head 'business'.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Rajagopalan and Rajagopala Ayyangar, JJ., and the question referred has been answered against the appellant. The High Court has held that the transaction in question was an adventure in the nature of trade and so the respondent was justified in taxing the amount in question under the head business for the relevant year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal findings on facts justified; mixed law/fact question properly resolved by applying legal principles to facts.

holdings.text: Whether transaction is adventure in nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact.

anchor.surface_text: more convenient to describe the question involved as a mixed question of law and fact. That is the view expressed by this Court in the case of Meenakshi Mills, Madurai

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires applying legal principles (elements of 'trade') to primary facts; reviewable under s.66(1) unlike pure fact; consistent with Edwards v Bairstow and Indian precedents (Meenakshi Mills, Oriental Investment).

holdings.text: Inference that transaction is adventure in nature of trade justified on proved facts and circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: it would be more appropriate to frame the question in this form whether, on the facts and circumstances proved in the case, the inference that the transaction in question is an adventure in the nature of trade is in law justified

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper framing of question under s.66(1); primary facts accepted, legal effect examinable; here justified.

holdings.text: No principle or formula governs all cases; character determined by total effect of relevant factors/circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: This question has been the subject-matter of several judicial decisions and in dealing with it all the judges appear to be agreed that no principle can be evolved which would govern the decision of all cases

holdings.reasoning_summary: Survey of precedents shows no universal test; borderline cases require weighing all factors (trader status, allied business, commodity nature/quantity, improvement, incidents, repetition, pride of possession).

holdings.text: Purchase with sole/exclusive intention to resell at profit raises strong (rebuttable) presumption of adventure in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: Was the purchase made with the intention to resell it at a profit ? It is often said that a transaction of purchase followed by resale can either be an investment or an adventure in the nature of trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention test: sole purpose distinguishes from investment (where resale secondary); rebuttable by other factors; supported by Rutledge, clarified Livingston.

holdings.text: Isolated/single transaction can be adventure in nature of trade if possesses essential trade features.

anchor.surface_text: When s. 2, sub-s. (4), refers to an adventure in the nature of trade it clearly suggests that the transaction cannot properly be regarded as trade or business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allied to but not full trade; 'single plunge' ok if trade-like; rejects 'one swallow no summer' or periodicity tests (Shaw Wallace pictorial similes irrelevant).

holdings.text: Edwards v Bairstow consistent with treating character of transaction as mixed law/fact.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it seems to us that in effect this decision is not inconsistent with the view we have taken about the character of the question raised before us in the present appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: House of Lords: inference examinable if misdirects on law (characteristics of trade); same result whether pure fact, law, or mixed.

holdings.text: Income-tax authorities justified in taxing Rs.43,887 as business income.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was right in taking the view that, on the facts and circumstances proved in this case, the transaction in question is an adventure in the nature of trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from h1; under s.2(4), s.10 IT Act.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Rajagopalan and Rajagopala Ayyangar, JJ., and the question referred has been answered against the appellant.
